header_1: H5N1 in Wild birds in Hong Kong
content_1: .  The Chiu Lut Sau Memorial Secondary School in Yuen Long closed on Friday, December 16, after a sick black-headed gull found on the school grounds tested positive for H5N1 bird flu.  The black-headed gull died on December 13 the day after it was found.  The Agriculture, Fisheries & Conservation Department said there were no unusual number of deaths or signs of avian influenza in local poultry farms and wholesale markets.Similarly, a Oriental magpie robin was found dead at the Ju Ching Chu Secondary School in Yuen Long on December 17.  The dead robin tested positive for highly pathogenic avian influenza in a preliminary examination.  Officers from the Agriculture, Fisheries & Conservation Department have inspected two chicken farms in close vicinity of the school but found no bird flu symptoms.  These farms will be put under enhanced surveillance.
content_2: .  In the Khulna and Dhaka Divisions of Bangladesh, four separate poultry farms experienced outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza from November 12 to December 18.  Out of 14,984 susceptible birds on the farms, 1,257 birds died from the disease, while the remaining 13,727 bird were culled to prevent the spread of the virus.  The birds tested positive for the H5N1 virus at the Bangladesh Livestock Research Institute and the Field Disease Investigation laboratories.  The source of the outbreaks remains unknown.  Control measures include movement control of poultry and disinfection of affected premises.
header_3: H5N1 in Poultry in Hong Kong
content_3: .  After a chicken that died at a wholesale poultry market in Long Sha, Kowloon tested positive for H5N1 bird flu, the remaining 17,000 chickens at the market were culled to prevent the spread of the disease.  Additionally, the Hong Kong government suspended the imports of live chickens from mainland China as well as the trading of live chickens for 21 days to further prohibit the spread of the virus.  A government spokesman said it is unknown if the dead chicken was a local chicken or imported from China, adding that the market would be emptied of birds and disinfected.  The last two large poultry culling exercises in Hong Kong took place in June 2008.
content_4: .  The World Health Organization was notified by the Ministry of Health and Population of Egypt of two human cases of highly pathogenic avian influenza infection.  A mother and child in the Dakahlia Governorate of Egypt developed bird flu symptoms on November 26.  The mother, who was 24 weeks pregnant, was admitted to a hospital on December 3, received oseltamivir, but died on December 3.  The child was hospitalized on December 2, received oseltamivir, and is currently in stable condition.  Prior to infection, the mother and child had exposure to both sick and dead backyard chickens and turkeys.  Of the 155 cases of human infection of H5N1 bird flu confirmed in Egypt, 53 have been fatal.
header_5: H5N1 in Humans in Hong Kong
content_5: .  In relation to the wild bird report for Hong Kong above, the 48-year-old woman who picked up the sick black-headed gull later found infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza, without any protection.  She developed a fever, sore throat, and diarrhea the next day and was admitted to the Princess Margaret Hospital for isolation and laboratory testing.  Her tests produced negative results for the Influenza A virus with all subtypes.  The Public Health Laboratory Services Branch is now conducting tests for bird flu on the womanâ€™s 11-year-old son, who recovered from a fever and cough earlier in the week.  He was also admitted to Princess Margaret Hospital as a precautionary measure, and his test results are currently pending.
